subject: Technology
title: Cable TV: Hundreds of Channels
description: A short lesson to help you apply Cable TV: Hundreds of Channels.

hook.text: Three channels became 30, then 300. Cable TV gave viewers more choice than they knew what to do with.

buildup.text: Cable began in the 1940s to improve reception in mountainous areas. By the 1980s, it was delivering dozens of new channels.

discovery.text: MTV, CNN, ESPN, and HBO launched on cable. Each created a channel devoted entirely to one type of content.

twist.text: More channels meant smaller audiences per show. The era of 50 million people watching the same program ended.

climax.text: Cable fragmented culture. Instead of shared experiences, people retreated into niche interests and never overlapped.

punchline.text: More channels gave us more choice. Less in common.

quiz.question: How did cable TV change viewing culture?
options: Everyone watched the same shows on different channels
It fragmented audiences into niche interests with less shared culture
